Posts.Title: Elevated liver enzymes after chemo MaryNY ItsStillMe

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2008 03:37PM carol1949 wrote: passims, I chose to do chemo because I had positive lymphs and also I had a lot of trust in my oncologist whom I had known on a personal level for 6 years prior to being dx. I also needed the financial help that insurance offered.  Unfortunately, to go totally holistic can cost a lot of money.  Having said that... check out Patrick Quillin on line.  He offers much info regarding complimentary therapy as well as alternative should one choose that. For me, the faith in God is a given no matter which path you take.  If you go for traditional therapy, yu still need to believe God that you are doing what is right for you. I have a dear friend who is 10 years cancer free who refused all traditional therapy after 2 surgeries.  She went through Cancer Treatment Centers of America after a bad experience in her local community.  When she told them she didn't want chemo.. they supported her decision and offered her many resources for alternative therapies.  It is mind body and spirit to get through this challenge.  The main thing is for you to trust that the right information will come to you. Do lots of research and trust your heart. Hugs and peace
Posts.Title: refusal to do chemo treatment pasimms carol1949

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2008 02:27PM - edited Sep 26, 2008 02:30PM by carol1949 Hugs, Renee,  The feelings you are feeling right now are said to be the most common when you are immediately diagnosed. I felt exactly the same way... (just get it over with... I don't care!)  However, I would encourage you to take a little time to do some research and see if you really are at peace with this decision based on all of your findings as well as opinions from your doctors. I actually am scheduled for a modified radical mastectomy with NO recon.... on Oct. 21.  First of all, my tumor is so large and we were not able to shrink it as much as hoped... so the surgeon is also saying the mastectomy is best.  Even if he had of been able to do lumpectomy... I was leaning toward the mast... since I have heard too many stories of people who did not get clear margins and were back  in for another surgery.. in a short time.. and I was not interested in that.  Both my surgeon and oncologist have suggested that I should wait at least one year before any reconstruction if I choose it anyway.... so that made me feel much better.  My surgeon said he has many women come back after the year and say, "You know what, it isn't that bad, I am not interested in recon."  On the other hand, my oncologist  a woman, and personal friend, thinks I should have recon!  So,again it is very personal.  I am 58, but a very young 58 . My professionals told me to get Dr. Susan Love's breast book and I did.. but also did a lot of other research on my own. I am now at peace with the mastectomy decision, and look forward to the light at the end of the tunnel! Trust that the right information will come to you in your journey. So many of us put ourselves behind those around us in life, so just remember ...This time... it's all about you!!  It is body, mind and spirit!
Posts.Title: Should I have a full mastectomy? BooBee kjcsis

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 07:32PM carol1949 wrote: 35 tx for me also were a breeze.  I must say that complexion sometimes has much to do with it, just as it does in the sun.  I am dark complected w/ mediterannean background, where as a blone fair skinned person has thinner skin. I used alra, a product especially for radiation which was more soothing than the aquaphor that the radiologists tend to offer.  I was able to buy the alra at a boutique right in the hospital for about $12.  Well worth it. Much of this is positive attitude and affirmations in life.  Do your reserach and trust your heart.
Posts.Title: does it hurt? beacher4209 bher

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 06:08PM - edited Jan 29, 2011 06:09PM by carol1949 MrsM,  I didn't get sick at all though 22 weeks of chemo!  I did a lot of journal writing, listened to healing tapes and also had a wonderful friend who is now a 13 year bc survivor who did it holistically and was inspirational to me, even though I chose to do conventional tx. I will say, that from the steroids, I would feel very wired and not sleepy the first night of chemo, which was always a Thursday.  Sometimes, I would feel very tired on Sunday, but not always.  Never got sick not even one time!  I did get constipated one time!  That was not fun, but they prepare you for that. Healing from cancer is body, mind and spirit!  You don't have to be sick at all.  Your body is at "dis" ease at the moment and wants to be healthy!  You, too can heal yourself with the help of modern medicine and any other complimentary therapies you are comfortable with.  I recomment Louise Hay's You Can Heal Your Life, Why People Don't Heal and How they Can by Caroline Myss, Bernie Seigel, Deepak Chopra and also Beating Cancer With Nutrition by Dr. Patrick Quillon.
Posts.Title: If and when did you get sick after chemo treatments? DivineMrsM bdavis

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2010 04:26PM carol1949 wrote: Pure,  There is no "wrong" thought.  It is only a thought and thoughts can be changed.  I would not put my entire faith in medicine for healing, as I am a total believer that it is body, mind and spirit. There are so many protocols of treatment out there.  I was so fortunate that my oncologists believe in the word "CURE".   I am cured of cancer.  If 22 weeks of chemo followed by surgery and radiation didn't do it, taking a drug that blocks estrogen in my body, but destroys my bones is sure as heck not going to do it!  That is why, I have turned to a holistic approach to remain cancer free! There are so many options out there..... you just have to research it and trust the information.  Continuing to cut out body parts is not the answer.
Posts.Title: Am I Wrong in Thinking Pure Husband11

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2009 04:22PM - edited Jan 22, 2009 04:24PM by carol1949 Hugs to all you January ladies.  I had a modified radical mastectomy and all lymph nodes removed in Oct.  I would say the worst pain on a scale of 1-10 with ten being the worst... was a 2  !!! Relax... it is not a painful procedure.  Incidentally, at the hospital I went to they routinely numb the area where they put in the I V... so that didn't even hurt other than a very tiny sting. Now, I have completed all treatment and am cancer free!  Ladies, please remember this fight requires body, mind and spirit.. and you can be successful.  None of us with or without b/c are guaranteed anything more than this moment.... of this day... so though you may not feel like rejoicing.... try to appreciate every person you encounter and the beauty of the nature that surrounds you. My nurse navigator said I should have been the surgeon's poster child, as she said I looked better immediately after surgery, than she did coming to visit me!

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 06:24PM carol1949 wrote: Sweeeet pam and others.  Gosh, Pam.... I never heard of the shots you are talking about.  Unless you mean the biopsies.  I assume the reason kith had the double is because it appears that she is er/pr- her2+ which tends to be a more aggressive form.  Also, unfortunately, we have medical tests that can find tumors, but NOT cancer cells which is why they do the chemo and rads.  Having said that, trust your heart along with your research.  I do have a friend who is an 11 year cancer survivor who had surgery, then went totally holistic, using nutritional approaches along with supplements, counseling, sweat camps, etc.  11 years certainly speaks to MY heart! No matter, with all of us... I encourage all of you to please, please do your research regarding nutritional/ approaches to remaining cancer free.  Most of all Trust your heart and do what you are comfortable with. Incidentally, no recon here and also no plans for it.
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 10:20PM carol1949 wrote: Faithfulheart!  Indeed some of these posts are discouraging at best!  I do believe in the cure word.  It is a word widely used in my oncologist's office and I was told I would be cured!  I do believe with all my heart and mind that I am cured.  There were miracles in the time of the Bible, so why not now?  Miracles can and do still happen. I have a very dear friend who is 13 years cancer free and she did it totally holistically after having surgery.  There are so many options out there to negate estrogen in our bodies and  to create a healthy body, mind and spirit. I would highly suggest some research and reading.  I found Beating Cancer With Nutrition by Dr. Patrick Quillon to be very informational, also the Anti Cancer diet by Dr. David Serbin Schreiber.  You Can Heal Your Life by Louise Hay. I do believe cancer can be cured!   Do your research and trust that the right information will come to you.  We are all going to die someday.  It is just a fact of life.  Meanwhile, live life to the fullest.  Enjoy everything and everyone you encounter and cherish your family.
Posts.Title: Never hearing the word Cured!!!! faithfulheart jennifer1

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2008 08:12AM carol1949 wrote: Naomi and others on here! First of all... my oncologist told me to consider that any data we see is at least 5 years old by the time we see it!  Most studies are 5 years studies. Second, remember traditional medicine is not the only way to beat cancer.  In fact, I personally don't think traditional medicine alone can beat cancer.  It is body, mind and spirit. I highly recommend for you to do much research on complimentary treatments which can be used along with traditional. It can only help.  Dr. Patrick Quillin has authored a book Beating Cancer With Nutrition.  He is a former V P of Cancer Treatment Centers of America.  He gives much information on supplements as well as diet along with inspiration about patients who are NED after being given poor prognosis by some physicians. I have a friend who is 10 years cancer free who went holistic after losing a sister to b/c who had used traditional therapy.  She did have 2 surgeries, (the 2nd at CCT of A after a bad experience in her local town.  She then went holistic with the help of nutritionists, etc.  It CAN be done!! Knowledge is power!!  Don't keep your head in the sand and use only traditional meds... Trust the the right information will come to you.  If it speaks to your heart... try it!! God Bless us All and Godspeed!
Posts.Title: 80 % chance of it coming back!!! Naomi browneyes2323

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 04:34PM carol1949 wrote: Lago,  I'm with you!  Ladies!  No one of us is guaranteed anything more than this moment of this day....  with or without cancer. Sandee, your comment on looking through rose colored glasses grabbed my attention and I want o suggest a wonderful book called just that!  Through Rose Colored Glassesby Donna Deegan.  Donna is a news anchor from First Coast News in Jacksonville,FL.  She is at least a 3 x survivor and very inspirational!  Just today was the 26.5 run in Jax, which Donna co sponsors with Mayo Clinic.  All of the money earned stays in Jax to help women there and also for breast cancer research at Mayo in Jax!  She truly is making a difference!

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2010 09:42AM carol1949 wrote: Adnerb, first of all even without bc, it is normal to be constantly losing and replenishing hair.  When we have an illness, the hair is often the last thing to get much needed nourishment from our body.  Thyroid also can cause hair loss and often if you didn't have thyroid issues prior to bc, you do have them post bc.  So consider that. As for preparing to lose hair... many people chose to shave their head, as it is one of the few things we can control and considered a "Power" thing if you will.  My radiologist suggested for me to read Susan' Love's breast book which does help prepare you for anything that may come up.  Knowledge is power! I have better results with Phytologee hair loss products and you don't have to use them the rest of your life like Nioxin.  My hair is actually better than it was prior to bc now!

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2009 06:12PM carol1949 wrote: Who hasn't ever had a cold?  We sometimes get another cold, right?  Whenever our bodies are at "dis" ease, we have no guarantee that our body will always be as strong as we would like it to be. As for the medications we are sometimes prescribed to keep cancer free.  My understanding for instance in my case which is femora is that it negates the fertilizer effect of the estrogen in my body and in particular in my breast. I wish all of you to have peace of mind in whatever you choose to call this "thing" that has temporarily interrupted the routine of our life.  Sometimes, perhaps it was a good thing to be interrupted and reevaluate what our "peace" really is.  Remember to have fun!
Posts.Title: Do you consider yourself sick? shockedat39 kmccraw423

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2008 09:10PM carol1949 wrote: I think an interesting way to look at bc as with any other health issue is that our body is at "dis" ease.  Our bodies are meant to be healthy and that is where we should focus, mind, body and spirit! Interestingly, different physicians have different views.  My oncologists say I am "cured".  They do believe in the cured word and so do I !  Everyone has cancer cells in their body... it is just when they go wayward that they form tumors and invade tissues and/or organs., I would invite everyone on this site to do more research on holistic and complimentary therapies to staying healthy and building a strong immune system. Faith, Hope and Good Health!
Posts.Title: Do you consider yourself sick? shockedat39 kmccraw423

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 03:13PM - edited Jan 4, 2009 03:15PM by carol1949 Hope is  good thing:) I find it interesting... the choice of words.  My oncologist actually does believe in cure and tells me that my cancer was cured!  I actually have a letter that we used to restructure a mortgage where another physicial from my oncology group wrote:  This is a "curable" cancer! I also find that it is so important how our frame of mind is.  I wonder if any of you have read Louise Hay's You Can Heal Your Life.  My friend who is 11 years cancer free told me about it.  She had surgery and then refused chemotherapy and radiation.  She did many alternative things... but nothing really quacky!  The fact that she is now 11 years cancer free speaks to my heart!   Our bodies are at "dis" ease.  We do not have an illness!  Our bodies want to be healthy.  Everyone has cancer cells..  for some reason... our immune systems did not destroy our cancer cells that were duplicating. I choose NOT to be sick, nor do I have an illness.  My body is cancer free and I am a cancer survivor!  Think it, believe it!!
Posts.Title: Do you consider yourself sick? shockedat39 kmccraw423

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 12:22PM carol1949 wrote: Ladies, Respectfully, I just reviewed some of these postings once again.  I send hugs and hope to all. One reason I have never thought of myself as "sick" is that I have not felt sick one day since my dx.  I felt perfectly healthy and normal, other than my "inner self" being at "dis" ease.  For instance, I painted my living room 3 times in a month which was totally unlike me.  We were planning to move back to my husband's home and I should have been thrilled, but wasn't.   I found my cancer quite by accident at a routine gyno apt.   Did I get tired during tx? Yes, Was I sensitive to smells?  Only with the first couple of chemo treatments.  Other than that... I have not felt "sick" at all. IMHO, this fight takes body, mind and spirit.  One thing can not do it without the other! In regards to the insurance scenario.  That is a whole other issue our country is dealing with!  My husband works in the insurance industry. To say that I believe it is corrupt is an understatement.  Don't ever tell a Dr. that you have memory problems!  You will never buy life insurance.  It is a precursor to alzheimers!!
Posts.Title: Do you consider yourself sick? shockedat39 kmccraw423

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2009 03:32PM carol1949 wrote: wbts,  I am glad you made an appointment.  I also had similar symptoms prior to my diagnosis and kept thinking I was having an alergic reaction to deoderant, etc.  I kept changing deoderants and it wasn't helping.  I also had body odor that the deoderant wasn't keeping in check, and that had never been a problem for me prior to that.  I also have fibrocystic breasts and my tumor was between 2 cysts.  Therefore, when I felt the cyst, I was missing the tumor hiding between them. I urge you to look into Lugol's iodine immediately and read about it.  Then, check Susan Weed's Breast cancer? Breast Health.  You may be able to get it from your local library. Listen to your heart and do your research.  Remember, no matter what it is... it is your body, mind and spirit that is at hand. I wish you God Speed and a peaceful journey in whatever your needs are.

Posts.Title: Prayers for TerryO's Cathy dreamwriter carol1949

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2009 09:59AM - edited Sep 9, 2009 12:03PM by carol1949 Continued prayers are offered to you, Heidi, as well as to all on this site.Valsgrandma is so right.  Statistics don't always show the entire picture.  My radiologist actually told me he has seen miracles when he had nothing more to offer the patient. Sometimes we find something that haunts our heart.  I had that experience Sunday at Mass while visiting a church with my friend who is struggling with a personal issue.  I heard this lovely melody and was led to research the composer... Michael Joncas.  The song is called Come to Me.  You can Google it and listen to the entire song on Rhapsody, but I downloaded it from Amazon, because it was easier.  I must say, the little speakers on my computer don't do it justice, but when I put my headphones on... it blew me away!  I think I have listened to it at least 24 times since yesterday!  Perhaps someone could offer you the opportunity to hear it and see if it blesses you the way it has me.  If not... consider whatever speaks to YOUR heart . Michael Joncas is a priest who has many cd's available, but the harmony in this piece is lovingly haunting. Prayers for peace to your heart.

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2009 06:36PM carol1949 wrote: Janet.  I personally believe all things happen for a reason.  I had a mastectomy on one breast.  Though, I considered having both sides... through all of my research and consults w/ my surgeon and my oncologist, who, incidentally is a personal friend... I chose NOT to have it. There is no indication that a prophylactic mastectomy guarantees that you will remain cancer free.  It can give a false security.  Please do lots of research including Dr. Susan Love, but I HIGHLY recommend for you to read Dr. Patrick Quillin's Beating Cancer With Nutrition.  Cutting off body parts is not the answer!  You can also find an abundance of information right on these boards suggesting complimentary therapies that are highly successful. After  chemo, single mastectomy, and rads... I am cancer free and plan to stay that way by rebuilding a strong immune system.  I have a dear friend who is 11 years cancer free and did it with surgery and NO chemo or rads.  it can be done!

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2008 06:45PM carol1949 wrote: Lisa,  I would tell you to follow your heart, intuition, whatever you want to call it.  My oncologist approves of Mono Vie and said many patients tell her they feel better and not so tired during chemo.  She also told me that University of FL is doing a study on Mona Vie in regard to chemotherapy. I would highly recommend for you to Google Dr. Patrick Quillin.  He is a Dr. of nutrition and former VP of Cancer Treamtment centers of America.  He explains his theories, along with documented results.  AT CTCA they use many supplements along with chemo which he explains enhanced the effectiveness of the chemo, while minimizing side effects.  He does NOT sell supplements, but tells you how to prioritize what you might need.  I was able to borrow his book from my local Public Library. Also, my nurse navigator recently told me she just read his book and was most impressed and thinks he is right.  She says so many areas are behind in this realm and she welcomed the information to be able to offer to people who do want some options. Good luck in your journey.
Posts.Title: MonaVie and Chemo? Lisa1964 Caya

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2008 07:46PM carol1949 wrote: patrickquillin.com/resume.html Unfortunately, there are always going to be these things.... but anyone can check the rest of his resume and see that perhaps the doctorate degree is not the most important part of his qualifications. The good thing is there are so many cross references that I found in what he suggests and one can easily look them up for themselves. My oncologist is familiar with him and thinks that there is nothing that can hurt you.... so it again is a matter of your comfort level.  I personally, certainly don't take everything he suggests, but didn't find anything that I thought was "quacky"! The important thing is we are all sharing our thoughts and opinions.  You are so right.. that just because it is in a book doesn't mean it is fact.  I appreciate your sharing your information.

I still liken it to what will they do next... at what point are we going to be led like sheep to slaughter, work camps, or whatever they decide they want to do with us!
Posts.Title: Full body scanners and foobs OLBinNJ Leah_S

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2010 08:34PM carol1949 wrote: Mom,.  Certainly it is food for thought.  You don't mention what your normal hair color is.  Perhaps you might like highlights or a method of off scalp coloring.  Minardi in NY does a lot of off scalp color which is ultimately the better option if you have concerns.  Hair color does have carcinogens, and the darker colors have higher concentratons than the lighter colors.  However when they do these tests, many times they inject rats w/ concentrations so high that it would be equivalent to actually drinking the haircolor in high amounts! I colored mine initially, but having had black hair most of my life, as I age, I find that the platinum streaks are actually more attractive and highlight my complexion.... so am enjoying the freedom. There are lots of choices.
Posts.Title: Who dyes their hair? Mom3 ruthbru

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2010 07:02PM carol1949 wrote: Fearless,Typically, warmer tones are more flattering to most people as they reflect more light than cool tones.  When you look at photos of hairstyles and colors, also notice the eye color.  Eyecolor also makes a difference.  Most people with blue eyes make more attractive blondes than people w/ brown eyes.  You could also consider some face framing highlights to add some dimension to your hair.  When we study haircolor, we study children's hair.  Notice how most children have many shades within their hair.  That is why to color our hair all one color tends to look flat and if too dark, sometimes will look like shoe leather! You are right, if you are pale, you probably do want some depth.  Many times a honey blonde is lovely and you probably shouldn't go lighter than that.... perhaps a few lights around your face in a honey tone might be nice.
Posts.Title: Who dyes their hair? Mom3 ruthbru

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2010 01:44PM carol1949 wrote: Hugs, blondie, Allow yourself a few moments to fall apart, if you feel the need, and then pick yourself up with the help of your angels and those of us on this site who care. I would like to suggest a couple of books that I found very helpful in this fight.  It may be time to look at your alternatives and adjust to whatever speaks to your heart.  For everyone that is different, and that is OK ! I found Beating Cancer With Nutrition by Patrick Quillin to be very helpful also Anti Cancer Book by David Schrieber (sp?)  You Can Heal Your Life by Lousie Hay  and last but not least Through Rose Colored Glasses by Donna Deegan. Donna is a news anchor in Jacksonville, FL who is a 3 x survivor, most recently of lung mets.  She now has gone holistic as a complimentary therapy to traditional tx.  You can Google her and read about her, as you can all of these books You can beat this!! .
Posts.Title: Had a rotten downer week! blondie45 blondie45

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2010 02:47AM carol1949 wrote: Feria isn't a bad product.  It is L'oreal.  Just keep in mind it is an analine derivitive product and does have carcinogens.  The darker the pigment or color, the more carcinogens in the product.  So, maybe opt for a lighter shade than you might have used in the past.  As our hair turns gray which means losing pigment, typically, our skin tone loses some pigment as well, which is why lighter shades tend to be more flattering as we age.
Posts.Title: Who dyes their hair? Mom3 ruthbru

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2009 05:49PM carol1949 wrote: My hair didn't fall out in clumps either.  First after about 3-4 weeks, my scalp got kind of tingly and dry and my hair felt very dry and lifeless.  Then, I noticed hairs falling down inside my blouse and it was just kind of uncomfortable.  I think if I had it to do over again, I would have just waited and observed.  I am a hairstylist, so it was no big deal for me.  It's just hair!  I think many encourage shaving mainly for the pshycological factor of it being something that YOU or WE have control over.  I also found it most uncomfortable to wear a wig and most of the time, wore a baseball cap when I went out. Hang in there.  It will be over b4 you know it and then it will all seem like a blur! Best Wishes to you... carol
Posts.Title: My hair is not following out Pure carol1949

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 10:26PM carol1949 wrote: Hi all,  I too started chemo 6 weeks ago.  It is interesting how the time frames differ. I am looking at every 2 weeks a/c then adding taxol sometime at their discretion.  I had a very large tumor which we are trying to shrink for a lumpectomy.... so am looking at surgery yet down the road and they are recommending radiation, which I will look at when the time comes! So far, the emend has helped and the other anti-nausea drugs also.  I still have kind of a lump in the throat feeling and just kind of feel a little punk.  I was a hairstylist and had just retired, so am grateful I don't have to work through this.  Wigs!?  Well, human hair are always cooler, but they are a lot of work.  You have to shampoo and blow dry them just like your own hair.  You really don't have to pay a fortune, though you can find them for reasonable prices even under $100.  Shop the internet.  Also, the synthetic ones are easy, but hot.  In the big picture of "LIFE"  it is just hair!  I always told my clients this and it is so true.  The hair loss is the least of my worries!  Hats, scarfs, they all work, it is just that your head gets sensitive and I find I take them off all around the house, where ever I happen to be when I have had enough! So far chemo isn't the horror that I had thought it would be.  I try to think of it like a song of I'm gonna Wash those cancer cells right out of my hair.  God Bless You all, and just remember to check out complimentary therapies as well.  They make a lot of sense!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Title: How do you say goodbye? Nanalinda konakat

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 06:42PM carol1949 wrote: Reiki for Cancer Pain and Fatigue Pain and fatigue are almost universal side effects of cancer and cancer treatment. Beginning in the late 1990s, a number of studies found that reiki treatment significantly reduced the fatigue, pain, and anxiety, and improved the overall quality of life in cancer patients. Particularly striking was the reduction in fatigue. This is believed to be a result of the rebalancing of energy in areas of the body experiencing disease and discomfort. Reiki treatments allowed patients to better control their pain and reduce their dependence on conventional pain opiod medications Incidentally, MD Anderson, Sloan Kettering, and CCTA are all routinely making Reiki available to their patients.
Posts.Title: Ladie's, I need your help please!!!!!!!!! faithfulheart carol1949

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2008 02:48PM carol1949 wrote: Ladies,  I have to attribute it to prayer and meditations, as I don't know why else! Basically I had absolutely NO pain!  I have some numbness and very little discomfort, but really no pain.  I recall the nurse in recovery telling me she was giving me something for pain and I asked how she knew I was in pain and she said, "Because you are frowning". Other than that... I had one other pain med by iv on the day of surgery... and then that evening switched to loritab.  I took 1 a day for few days near bedtime, and now am not taking anything.  It is just over one week. I had one drain out last Friday and the other one last Monday.  Tomorrow, I meet w/ surgeon to go over path reports! Hugs and prayers to all.
Posts.Title: Surgery's over, Now what? Firni lktracey

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 02:25PM carol1949 wrote: my 2 cents!  I work as a hairstylist and have just in the last 3 months met several women who are anywhere from 5 year survivors - 21 year survivors.  They all had chemo and/ or radiation.  Keep in mind that all studies take at least 5 years to compile information, so by the time we even get the information it is outdated to some extent. Having said that... I am totally supportive of our right to choose.  For me... I chose complimentary therapies.  (Meaning I used traditional because I trusted my friend and oncologist), but I also used some unconventional therapies and I am doing very well in this healing journey.  Just keep doing your research and trust "YOUR heart".  What speaks to your heart, may not speak to others and that is ok!

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2010 03:35PM carol1949 wrote: Wow Lyn,, I would run not walk from those Dr.'s  Sound like they don't know what the heck they are doing!  I also have had several cysts aspirated... As Beesie says it is just a pin prick... and you're out of there!    I will recommend however for you to take Lugol's iodine.  It has been shown to totally erradicate fybrocytic breasts.  You can Google it and read about it.  I take about 6 drops per day in milk or juice.  My oncologist said she thinks the lumps in my remaining breast are smaller because of the Lugol's.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 07:53PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 11:05AM by carol1949 They gave me a "huggie" with soft breast forms right at the hospital when I had the surgery.  They are very comfortable and soft for the first couple of months.  (I also had rads after) so didn't even bother w/ prosthesis till later.  We have a major medical dept store where I live and they keep the forms in stock, so it is just a matter of being fitted & you can leave w/ the form. I won't try to encourage you one way or the other regarding having the 2nd breast removed, but would ask you to be thorough in your research. Strangely, my oncologist (who is a personal friend ) asked if I was considering it... assuming I was going for Reconstruction, which I ultimately decided against.  My surgeon said no medical reason to remove it and removing can give one a false sense of security, since you can still get cancer in the chest wall.  (That was my determining factor.)  I would suggest also to get Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book.  I found it very helpful.

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2010 08:59PM carol1949 wrote: riley!   I am not sure if it is doable for "your" hair... since I can't see it!  That is why I advised you to go to a stylist for a consultation!  One of my favorite experiences is years ago when i spent at least 30 minutes in a consult w/ a young girl who wanted to be blonde.  I showed her pictures, hair swatches... you name it!  All of a sudden she showed me a black and white photo of a blone and said, "I like that color!"    I rest my case!   lololol  There certainly are slate type colors available, whether they would be advisable for your hair and your complexion are a whole different story!

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 08:02PM carol1949 wrote: riley,  It depends on what you are considering gray!  There are ash blonde colors that have a drab look due to the base of the color and many times people think they look gray.  You might also consider having your hair highlighted and then toned with a platinum type toner.  I also am a stylist/colorist.  Just go to a nice salon in your area and ask for a consultation.  That is the best approach.  Most people don't charge for a consultation and if you have pictures... bring them.  A picture is worth a thousand words!

Posts.Content: May 12, 2011 11:09PM carol1949 wrote: Check into Lugol's iodine.  It has been shown to erradicate fibrocystic breasts.  I had over 30 cysts in one breat at one time.  The danger is that they can block the view of a potential serious lump on a mammogram.  Do some research.

I am reading where more and more people are being incouraged even by physicians to become more holistic and use alternative therapies as well as traditional.

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2008 05:45PM carol1949 wrote: I also am diagnosed with Stage III b/c + lymph nodes.  I am grateful to meet other people with tumors as large as mine.  My main one is about 7 cm with another area all totalled they estimated at 12.5cm.  I am going through 16-22 weeks of pre surgical chemo.  Finished 4 a/c.  Though it wasn't fun, it certainly wasn't the horror stories of years ago.  Next comes taxol.  Have any of you had experience with that?  If so, please share.  I have a friend who had surgery, declined all other traditional therapy and is cancer free 10 years out!!  Praise God for that.  I think we all know we need the medical experts, but I am planning to do the complimentary therapies as well.  Those of you who are still cancer free, what are you doing? God's Love, Healing powers, and Grace are circulating in my life! I am not Afraid, for the Lord, thy God shall not Fail me Nor Forsake me.
Posts.Title: needing some hope ekenny315 Maryiz

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2010 02:48PM carol1949 wrote: All good suggestions here!  I also took up a couple of projects.  Did a needlepoint pillow, did some scrapbooking for my 2 daughters and made them some real cute Mary Engelbright aprons!  I also play paino and enjoy music. One of the most beneficial things I did was keep a journal, even of my darkest thoughts and then I trashed them and cleansed my mind of them.  I read several uplifting books and listened to healing tapes.  One when I couldn't sleep that was guaranteed to put me to sleep was Andrew Weil, Sound Body, Sound Minds.  Try it!   Remember, this too shall pass.  I can't believe that I finally feel back to normal again, but really feel even better and more at peace than I have in a very long time.
Posts.Title: So I stopped working. Now what?? AnacortesGirl cagney

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2011 09:42PM carol1949 wrote: Texas,  Does it appear that there is a fungus present in the nail bed?  If so, you can try tea tree oil topically, or try using alcohol, and then white vinegar.  When you take Biotin, since it is one of the B vitamins, you should probably take a B complex since the B vitamins are designed to work together.  I would definitely ask the Dr. about it though or perhaps a homeopath person.  My oncologist's office actually recommended using a nail type hardener during tx.  I just don't know what your nail looks like, but good luck and don't give up!
Posts.Title: Still losing fingernails -- 2 years after taxotere Texas357 Texas357

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2008 06:47AM carol1949 wrote: I also had chemo prior to what will be a modified radical mastectomy.  My tumor was 6.5 cm, but had other areas which totaled 12.5 cm if they are cancer... they were "suspicious".  I have done a ton of research and it seems it is becoming much more common to do the chemo first for a few reasons.  It gives them opportunity to see which chemo's may be most effective, allows for shrinkage prior to surgery and also helps find and destroy any cells which may be floating elsewhere in the body.  Tests, at present only pick up cancer cells if they have already formed a tumor.  My breast tumor was missed on a mammogram even though we know it has been there for probably 5 years.  Which actually means it was probably missed on more than one mammogram,as I had them regularly! I highly suggest that you do tons of research including complimentary therapies.  Chemo only has a 30-65% success rate, and complimentary therapies can enhance the chemo while minimizing the s/e's.  Check out in particular Dr. Patrick Quillin formerly of a major cancer treatment center.  My oncologist approved of him and his book called Beating Cancer With Nutrition. Trust that the right information will come to you.,
Posts.Title: Chemo first? Payne petelzmom

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2010 03:26PM carol1949 wrote: There is a very uplifting book called Through Rose Colored Glasses by Donna Deegan ( A News anchor for First Coast News, in Jacksonville, FL).  Donna is a 3 time bc survivor, stage 4 and she runs  and works out.  She organized the first ever marathon specifically to benefit breast cancer.  Some of her money goes to Mayo Clinic in Jax for bc research and the rest goes to her foundation to help women in need who are battling bc.  It is handled through Catholic Charities, and helps to pay mortgage, medicine, whatever the need is.

I did love the Teddy Bear, though and still have it! It had a poem something about to hug when you were scared, to cry on, etc.  And it is washable, but very good quality!
Posts.Title: What to Expect at Rads Office Pure carol1949

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2010 01:48PM carol1949 wrote: Regarding the dose... it is all computerized which is also why they ask your birthdate each time prior to tx.
Posts.Title: What to Expect at Rads Office Pure carol1949

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 04:56PM - edited Feb 10, 2010 04:57PM by carol1949 Wow!  What a difference in locations and physicians!  The first thing they did for me was hand me a beautiful white Teddy Bear with a beautiful poem wrritten on a colorful gift card!  Then, I met with the nurse who went over many things and took a history, and finally the radiation oncologist who told me the plan, and the only thing  I would have to worry about really was possible lymphedema.  He told me rads would cut "my" chance of recurrence by 50% and he thought it was a no brainer.  I was already on Femara, and vitamin E.  He just suggested not to do mega doses of any supplements, but had no problem with general use of supplements. My skin did fabulously, I got like a mild sunburn, and had a special cream specifically for radiation patients  to use.  One of the physicians on the team also was in favor of alternative/complimentary therapies and said he had seen miracles when he had nothing more to offer some patients! My oncology center also had a spa which offered Reiki on site, and also since it was a Catholic Hospital, we had Nuns who would come and pray with you.  They also had a guitar player play occassionally! P.S.  No tattoos!  They just drew on me with markers.
Posts.Title: What to Expect at Rads Office Pure carol1949
